title: China donates computer equipment to the Congolese Ministry of Posts, Telecommunications, and the Digital Economy for Mossaka Digital training center
description: On November 12, 2018, the Chinese Embassy handed over a donation of computer equipment to the Congolese Ministry of Posts, Telecommunications and the Digital Economy to support the project of equipping the digital training center for young people in Mossaka. The donation came from China's onsite storage, including laptops, desktops, printers, uninterruptible power supplies or inverters, and whiteboards of different sizes. According to the ADIAC source, this donation is estimated to be worth 17,000,000 CFA francs. Ma Fulin, the Chinese ambassador to the Congo, attended the handover ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China donates computer equipment to the Congolese Ministry of Posts, Telecommunications, and the Digital Economy for Mossaka Digital training center

# Description
On November 12, 2018, the Chinese Embassy handed over a donation of computer equipment to the Congolese Ministry of Posts, Telecommunications and the Digital Economy to support the project of equipping the digital training center for young people in Mossaka. The donation came from China's onsite storage, including laptops, desktops, printers, uninterruptible power supplies or inverters, and whiteboards of different sizes. According to the ADIAC source, this donation is estimated to be worth 17,000,000 CFA francs. Ma Fulin, the Chinese ambassador to the Congo, attended the handover ceremony.
justification: Project focuses on digital education and training, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of computer equipment for digital training center, focus on youth education

title: China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) financed the construction of dormitory in Pierre Passy Middle School in Congo (Linked to Project ID#59311)
description: In 2018, the Chinese company China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) financed the new school building of Pierre Passy Middle School in the Republic of Congo. CSCEC is also the contractor for this project, and the new buildings built had five classrooms, an administrative block, a laboratory, a boarding school, a library, compulsory housing, etc.. It took four months to complete and the construction area totaled more than 500 square meters. The financing amount is unknown.  On August 12, 2018, the completion ceremony was held at Pierre Passy Middle School. The ceremony was attended by the Chinese Ambassador and General Manager of China Construction West and West Africa. The company officially handed over the new buildings to the school.  During the ceremony, the Chinese Embassy in the Republic of Congo also donated a batch of teaching and living materials to the Ministry of Primary, Secondary and Literacy Education. The donated materials included computers, TV sets and office supplies (captured by Project ID#59311).
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 皮埃尔·帕西中学新校舍.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) financed the construction of dormitory in Pierre Passy Middle School in Congo (Linked to Project ID#59311)

# Description
In 2018, the Chinese company China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) financed the new school building of Pierre Passy Middle School in the Republic of Congo. CSCEC is also the contractor for this project, and the new buildings built had five classrooms, an administrative block, a laboratory, a boarding school, a library, compulsory housing, etc.. It took four months to complete and the construction area totaled more than 500 square meters. The financing amount is unknown.  On August 12, 2018, the completion ceremony was held at Pierre Passy Middle School. The ceremony was attended by the Chinese Ambassador and General Manager of China Construction West and West Africa. The company officially handed over the new buildings to the school.  During the ceremony, the Chinese Embassy in the Republic of Congo also donated a batch of teaching and living materials to the Ministry of Primary, Secondary and Literacy Education. The donated materials included computers, TV sets and office supplies (captured by Project ID#59311).
justification: Project focuses on educational infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of school buildings including classrooms, administrative block, laboratory, and boarding facilities; donation of educational materials

title: Chinese Embassy donates living and teaching materials to Pierre Passy Middle School (Linked to Project ID#59284)
description: On August 12, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in the Republic of Congo donated a batch of living and teaching materials to Pierre Passy Middle School in the Republic of the Congo. The donation was made during the completion ceremony of the new school building of Pierre Passi Middle School, which was financed and constructed by China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) (captured by Project ID#59284). Chinese Ambassador Ma Fulin attended the ceremony and made the donation. The founder of Passy Middle School, former ambassador to China, Vice President of the Constitutional Court, Passi, junior and intermediate education and literacy minister Makosso, the Lékoumou Department Governor, China Construction West Africa General Manager Shi Honggang, teachers and students of the school, and more than 200 local villagers attended the ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates living and teaching materials to Pierre Passy Middle School (Linked to Project ID#59284)

# Description
On August 12, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in the Republic of Congo donated a batch of living and teaching materials to Pierre Passy Middle School in the Republic of the Congo. The donation was made during the completion ceremony of the new school building of Pierre Passi Middle School, which was financed and constructed by China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) (captured by Project ID#59284). Chinese Ambassador Ma Fulin attended the ceremony and made the donation. The founder of Passy Middle School, former ambassador to China, Vice President of the Constitutional Court, Passi, junior and intermediate education and literacy minister Makosso, the Lékoumou Department Governor, China Construction West Africa General Manager Shi Honggang, teachers and students of the school, and more than 200 local villagers attended the ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure and materials donation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of living and teaching materials to school, construction of school building, education sector focus

title: Chinese government grants FCFA 26 billion to Congo for budget relief
description: On September 5, 2018, the Congolese President visited Beijing for the 7th Forum on Sino-African cooperation and signed five agreements about the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. One agreement is that China will grant FCFA 26 billion to the Republic of Congo. The funds will be used to help with budgetary pressures, according to Objectif Afrique Africa and Indian Ocean Directorate. The other four agreements involve the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Pointe Noire, the concession of the RN1 linking Pointe Noire to Brazzaville to be operated by the Franco-Chinese consortium EGIS / CSCEC, non-profit double taxation, and the construction of a training school for construction trades.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL BUDGET SUPPORT

# Title
Chinese government grants FCFA 26 billion to Congo for budget relief

# Description
On September 5, 2018, the Congolese President visited Beijing for the 7th Forum on Sino-African cooperation and signed five agreements about the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. One agreement is that China will grant FCFA 26 billion to the Republic of Congo. The funds will be used to help with budgetary pressures, according to Objectif Afrique Africa and Indian Ocean Directorate. The other four agreements involve the Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Pointe Noire, the concession of the RN1 linking Pointe Noire to Brazzaville to be operated by the Franco-Chinese consortium EGIS / CSCEC, non-profit double taxation, and the construction of a training school for construction trades.
justification: General budget support without specific environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Funds allocated for budgetary relief, no specific project details provided

title: China sends 25th medical team to Congo
description: In July 2018, China sent the 25th medical team to the Republic of Congo (援刚果（布）第25批医疗队). The team members come from 34 medical institutions in Tianjin city, involving 16 departments including internal, external, women, children, stomatology, ophthalmology. On July 24, the farewell ceremony for these members to go to Congo was held. On the same day, Ambassador Ma Fulin to the Congo (Brazzaville) and Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Mamina signed a new phase of the China-Government Medical Team Protocol, and the Minister of Health and Population Mikolo attended the ceremony. The Chinese medical team to Congo will be mainly working at the China-Congo Friendship Hospital in Brazzaville, the capital, and the Loandjili Hospital in Pointe Noire.  The 25th medical team finished its service in August 2019, when the 26th Chinese medical team was sent to the Republic of Congo").
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends 25th medical team to Congo

# Description
In July 2018, China sent the 25th medical team to the Republic of Congo (援刚果（布）第25批医疗队). The team members come from 34 medical institutions in Tianjin city, involving 16 departments including internal, external, women, children, stomatology, ophthalmology. On July 24, the farewell ceremony for these members to go to Congo was held. On the same day, Ambassador Ma Fulin to the Congo (Brazzaville) and Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Mamina signed a new phase of the China-Government Medical Team Protocol, and the Minister of Health and Population Mikolo attended the ceremony. The Chinese medical team to Congo will be mainly working at the China-Congo Friendship Hospital in Brazzaville, the capital, and the Loandjili Hospital in Pointe Noire.  The 25th medical team finished its service in August 2019, when the 26th Chinese medical team was sent to the Republic of Congo").
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services at hospitals, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese Ministry of Commerce held train course for Congolese Urban Planning workers
description: From April 12 to May 2, 2018, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce held a training course on Urban Planning and Construction for students from the Republic of Congo. This training was implemented by the Shanghai Business School. In July 2018, the Congolese Minister of Construction, Urban Planning and Housing sent a letter to the Chinese Ambassador and expressed the hope that the training will develop in the direction of academic education in the future, extend the training cycle, and set up scholarships for young people. The financial value of the training is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Commerce held train course for Congolese Urban Planning workers

# Description
From April 12 to May 2, 2018, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce held a training course on Urban Planning and Construction for students from the Republic of Congo. This training was implemented by the Shanghai Business School. In July 2018, the Congolese Minister of Construction, Urban Planning and Housing sent a letter to the Chinese Ambassador and expressed the hope that the training will develop in the direction of academic education in the future, extend the training cycle, and set up scholarships for young people. The financial value of the training is unknown.
justification: Training program focused on urban planning education with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Training course on Urban Planning and Construction, implemented by educational institution, focus on capacity building

title: Chinese Ministry of Commerce held training for 12 Congolese artisans in crocheting in China
description: In June 2018, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce funded a crocheting technical training course for 12 Congolese artisans (10 females and 2 males) in China. The training courses were held in Changsha, China from June 6 to August 14, 2018. The main course includes topics such as graphic design line drawing, the performance, use, maintenance, and common fault handling of the drawn hook weaver, color knowledge, various needle methods, product forming, rinsing, ironing process, and stain treatment. Participants will also go to Guangzhou and Shenzhen for investigation and research. The financial value of the training is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Commerce held training for 12 Congolese artisans in crocheting in China

# Description
In June 2018, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce funded a crocheting technical training course for 12 Congolese artisans (10 females and 2 males) in China. The training courses were held in Changsha, China from June 6 to August 14, 2018. The main course includes topics such as graphic design line drawing, the performance, use, maintenance, and common fault handling of the drawn hook weaver, color knowledge, various needle methods, product forming, rinsing, ironing process, and stain treatment. Participants will also go to Guangzhou and Shenzhen for investigation and research. The financial value of the training is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on skills training and capacity building without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Crocheting technical training course, education sector, skills development focus

title: CMEC restructures 2005 supplier’s credit for Power Transmission Network Associated with the Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#1049)
description: On December 19, 2005, China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed a supplier’s credit agreement worth $551,507,000 (or approximately worth CFA 321.7 billion) for the Power Transmission Network Associated with the Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project. It carried the following terms: a 17-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 0.2% interest rate, and 24 semi-annual repayments between 2011 and 2022. The proceeds of the supplier’s credit were to be used by the borrower to finance 85% of the cost of its $648,832,000 commercial contract with CMEC. The Republic of Congo agreed to cover the remaining 15% of the commercial contract cost ($97,325,000) itself. Over the lifetime of the supplier’s credit, the Republic of Congo agreed to repay $557,849,330.50 in principal and interest.   Then, on January 18, 2006, the supplier’s credit agreement was modified (in particular, Articles 6, 8, and 13). The project execution period was reduced from 5 years to 3.5 years and additional changes were introduced related to the name of the lender; the credit conditions; loan repayment and amortization table; the duration, validity, and termination of the credit; and the conditions of entry into force of the credit.   Then, on April 13, 2018, CMEC and the Republic of Congo signed another supplier’s credit agreement modification to reschedule the repayment terms. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan ($348,614,050) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 22-year maturity, an 8-year grace period, a 0.2% interest rate, and 14 semi-annual installments between June 2021 and December 2027. As such, the rescheduling agreement effectively increased the grace period of the supplier’s credit by an additional 3 years (from June 2018 to June 2021). After the restructuring of this loan, the net present value of total repayments to CMEC fell from $331,557,351.05 37 (before restructuring) to $274,445,470  (after restructuring). This increase represented a 17.2% reduction in net present value terms. As of April 13, 2018, the borrower had already repaid $207,876,503.54.   Under the terms of the rescheduling agreement, the borrower was responsible for making a $25,249,617 repayment (24,901,003 in principal and $348,614 in interest) on June 1, 2021 and a $25,224,716 repayment  ($24,901,003 in principal and $323,713 in interest)on December 1, 2021. However, according to the Republic of Congo's Ministry of Finance, neither of these repayments were made. Therefore, by the end of calendar year 2021, the Republic of Congo had approximately $50 million of principal and interest arrears to CMEC.  This project sought to build upon the CMEC-financed 120MW Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project (captured in Project ID#434). It involved connecting the Imboulou Hydropower Plant with several small power stations to construct a “major power channel” (or “energy boulevard”) between the cities of Pointe-Noire, Brazzaville and Ouésso. More specifically, it supported the construction of a load dispatching center (“redistribution center”); the construction and rehabilitation of 220kv transmission lines and very high voltage transformer plants between Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire (passing through Mindouli and Loudima); the construction of seven 220 KV and 110 KV high-voltage power stations in Djiri, Ngo, Gamboma, Oyo, Boundji, Owando and Djambala (including a 220kV Imboulou-Ngo segment, a 220kV Ngo-Brazzaville segment; a 220kV Ngo-Gamboma segment, a 220kV Oyo-Owando segment, and a 110kV Ngo-Djambala-Oyo-Boundji segment); the construction of underground 220kV transmission line in Tsiélampo; the construction of nine 30kV aerial lines measuring 242 km in length (including an Imboulou-Inoni-Mpoumako-Imvouba segment, an Inoni-Inoni2-Mbouambé-Léfini segment, an Imboulou-Mbé-Ngabé segment, and an Imboulou-Mpouya segment); the construction of four 20kV underground transmission lines to evacuate power from the Imboulou Hydroelectric Power Plant to the capital city of Brazzaville; and the construction of nine additional 220 kV and 110 kV high voltage lines (measuring 841 km in length). In total, the project sought to create a 1,588 km national electricity transmission network CMEC was the contractor responsible for implementation.  Construction started on May 28, 2009, and the project was completed on May 23, 2012. Project ID#1049 captures the original 2005 supplier’s credit and Project ID#73614 captures the 2018 debt rescheduling agreement.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 英布鲁水电站配套输变电工程 or 刚果(布)输变电工程 工程规 or 的刚果（布）英布鲁水电站配套输变 or 刚果输变电项目. This project is also known as the Transmission Line Substations for Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project. The French project title is Projet de Construction du Réseau de Transport d’Energie Associé à la Centrale d’imboulou or Construction du réseau de transport d'énergie électrique associé à la centrale hydroélectrique d'Imboulou or Réhabilitation des infrastructures du réseau de transport THT entre Pointe-Noire et Brazzaville or Le Projet de Réseau Intégré de Transport (Projet RIT) or La réhabilitation de la ligne Très Haute Tension 220kv Loudima-Mindouli du projet THT au Congo.  2. In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it identifies a $264 million China Eximbank loan in 2009 for this project. However, AidData relies on the face value of the supplier’s credit ($551,507,000) and the commitment year (2005) of the supplier’s agreement that is specified in the agreement itself. 3. CMEC used to stand for China National Machinery & Equipment Import & Export Corporation, but it now refers to China Machinery Engineering Corporation. 4. The April 13, 2018 debt rescheduling agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20488096-cog_2005_490. 5. A more detailed analysis of the April 13, 2018 debt rescheduling can be found at https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/bargaining-beijing-tale-two-borrowers-revised-feb2021.pdf and https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/gardner-et-al-bargaining-with-beijing-data-revised.xlsx.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
CMEC restructures 2005 supplier’s credit for Power Transmission Network Associated with the Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#1049)

# Description
On December 19, 2005, China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed a supplier’s credit agreement worth $551,507,000 (or approximately worth CFA 321.7 billion) for the Power Transmission Network Associated with the Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project. It carried the following terms: a 17-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 0.2% interest rate, and 24 semi-annual repayments between 2011 and 2022. The proceeds of the supplier’s credit were to be used by the borrower to finance 85% of the cost of its $648,832,000 commercial contract with CMEC. The Republic of Congo agreed to cover the remaining 15% of the commercial contract cost ($97,325,000) itself. Over the lifetime of the supplier’s credit, the Republic of Congo agreed to repay $557,849,330.50 in principal and interest.   Then, on January 18, 2006, the supplier’s credit agreement was modified (in particular, Articles 6, 8, and 13). The project execution period was reduced from 5 years to 3.5 years and additional changes were introduced related to the name of the lender; the credit conditions; loan repayment and amortization table; the duration, validity, and termination of the credit; and the conditions of entry into force of the credit.   Then, on April 13, 2018, CMEC and the Republic of Congo signed another supplier’s credit agreement modification to reschedule the repayment terms. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan ($348,614,050) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 22-year maturity, an 8-year grace period, a 0.2% interest rate, and 14 semi-annual installments between June 2021 and December 2027. As such, the rescheduling agreement effectively increased the grace period of the supplier’s credit by an additional 3 years (from June 2018 to June 2021). After the restructuring of this loan, the net present value of total repayments to CMEC fell from $331,557,351.05 37 (before restructuring) to $274,445,470  (after restructuring). This increase represented a 17.2% reduction in net present value terms. As of April 13, 2018, the borrower had already repaid $207,876,503.54.   Under the terms of the rescheduling agreement, the borrower was responsible for making a $25,249,617 repayment (24,901,003 in principal and $348,614 in interest) on June 1, 2021 and a $25,224,716 repayment  ($24,901,003 in principal and $323,713 in interest)on December 1, 2021. However, according to the Republic of Congo's Ministry of Finance, neither of these repayments were made. Therefore, by the end of calendar year 2021, the Republic of Congo had approximately $50 million of principal and interest arrears to CMEC.  This project sought to build upon the CMEC-financed 120MW Imboulou Hydropower Plant Project (captured in Project ID#434). It involved connecting the Imboulou Hydropower Plant with several small power stations to construct a “major power channel” (or “energy boulevard”) between the cities of Pointe-Noire, Brazzaville and Ouésso. More specifically, it supported the construction of a load dispatching center (“redistribution center”); the construction and rehabilitation of 220kv transmission lines and very high voltage transformer plants between Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire (passing through Mindouli and Loudima); the construction of seven 220 KV and 110 KV high-voltage power stations in Djiri, Ngo, Gamboma, Oyo, Boundji, Owando and Djambala (including a 220kV Imboulou-Ngo segment, a 220kV Ngo-Brazzaville segment; a 220kV Ngo-Gamboma segment, a 220kV Oyo-Owando segment, and a 110kV Ngo-Djambala-Oyo-Boundji segment); the construction of underground 220kV transmission line in Tsiélampo; the construction of nine 30kV aerial lines measuring 242 km in length (including an Imboulou-Inoni-Mpoumako-Imvouba segment, an Inoni-Inoni2-Mbouambé-Léfini segment, an Imboulou-Mbé-Ngabé segment, and an Imboulou-Mpouya segment); the construction of four 20kV underground transmission lines to evacuate power from the Imboulou Hydroelectric Power Plant to the capital city of Brazzaville; and the construction of nine additional 220 kV and 110 kV high voltage lines (measuring 841 km in length). In total, the project sought to create a 1,588 km national electricity transmission network CMEC was the contractor responsible for implementation.  Construction started on May 28, 2009, and the project was completed on May 23, 2012. Project ID#1049 captures the original 2005 supplier’s credit and Project ID#73614 captures the 2018 debt rescheduling agreement.
justification: Project primarily involves construction of transmission infrastructure to connect renewable energy sources, but does not directly generate renewable energy itself
evidence: Construction of 220kv transmission lines, high voltage transformer plants, and extensive grid network to connect Imboulou Hydropower Plant and other power stations

title: PowerChina and Weihai donate teaching materials to China-Congo Friendship Primary School
description: On January 24, 2018, Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) and Weihai International Economic and Technical Corporation jointly donated a batch of teaching materials to a primary school in Massengo in Congo. This school is one of the three China-Congo Friendship schools (see Project ID#1071), the construction of which was funded by the Chinese government and undertaken by Weihai international. Ambassador Xia Huang attended the donation ceremony and handed over the supplies to the school. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
PowerChina and Weihai donate teaching materials to China-Congo Friendship Primary School

# Description
On January 24, 2018, Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) and Weihai International Economic and Technical Corporation jointly donated a batch of teaching materials to a primary school in Massengo in Congo. This school is one of the three China-Congo Friendship schools (see Project ID#1071), the construction of which was funded by the Chinese government and undertaken by Weihai international. Ambassador Xia Huang attended the donation ceremony and handed over the supplies to the school. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of educational materials with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of teaching materials to primary school, education sector focus

title: Chinese Embassy donates living materials to Provincial Government of Pointe-Noire in Congo
description: From April 27 to 29, 2018, Ambassador Ma Fulin met with heads of local government in Pointe-Noire in Congo and donated a batch of living materials to the provincial government of Pointe-Noire. The donation aims to help improve the living conditions of public servants. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER COMMODITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates living materials to Provincial Government of Pointe-Noire in Congo

# Description
From April 27 to 29, 2018, Ambassador Ma Fulin met with heads of local government in Pointe-Noire in Congo and donated a batch of living materials to the provincial government of Pointe-Noire. The donation aims to help improve the living conditions of public servants. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of living materials for social welfare purposes without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of living materials to improve living conditions of public servants
